_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: BOTH HOLDING TANKS, TRANSFER HOSES MANUFACTURE DATES, AND ALL EQUIPMENT ASSOCIATED WITH THEM.  ALSO
_prev_prog_2.Description:
Prevention Program

This facility checks the maintenance and condition of the holding tanks and equipment prior to first use in the spring and periodically throughout the season.  When application begins for anhydrous ammonia, the nurse tanks are checked daily.  When in use, they are filled and are returned to the facility and checked before being refilled again.  Any minor discrepancies are corrected on the spot as they are noted.  For major discrepancies, nurse tanks are taken out of service and positioned in a designated area until time permits an employee to fix the problem.

The few personnel that does work with anhydrous ammonia has worked with it for years.  They are familiar with the operation of the transferring of products from the holding tanks to the nurse tanks as well as the maintenance procedures.

The corrosion that was listed is the hazard review section, under the major hazards identified is in regards to the nurse tanks which needs to be painted due to corrosion.  All the nurse tanks are scheduled to be repainted this summer and be completed before September 15, 1999.

There is no mitigation system in use since the location of anhydrous ammonia is located in the open on the southwest corner of the property.  Any release of the product would go up into atmosphere as a gas release.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.  The Facility Policy

The owners, management, and employees of Whitehouse Grain Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2.  Facility Information

The primary activity at the facility is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  We also do custom spraying of chemicals for our customers as another service.

Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application for farmers.  The maximum quantity stored on site would be 200,000 pounds in our two storage tanks; which the largest is a 30,000 gallon tank and the smaller tank is 18,000 gallon.

3.  The worst case release scenario and the alternative release scenario.

The worst case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of a holding tank released as a gas over 10 (ten) minutes.  The maximum quantity released would be 120,000 pounds, which represents the volume of the largest storage tank at 85 percent capacity as limited by design standards.  The distance to the end point (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 1.48 miles; based upon a wind speed of 1.5 meters/second.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               The alternative release scenario based on the most likely potential incident is a release from a break in a transfer hose.  The distance to the end point (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is .32 miles. 

4.  The accidental release prevention program.

The facility has implemented the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safe

ty and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia."

5.  The five year accident history.

There has been no accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at this facility.  Nor to our knowledge, have resulted in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

6.  The emergency response program

The facility has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 1910.38, and a written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

The plan includes employees to shut-off the appropriate values to stop any small accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  Otherwise, the fire department would be notified and full cooperation would be given to them to take the necessary steps to contain, stop the leak, and determine if we need to implement steps to evacuate the area or shelter in place.  

7.  Planned change to improve safety.

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to access the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementations at this time.

8.  Other

The latitude and longitude location description code was entered as other.  It represents the location of the 360 Communication tower, which is located near the south-east corner of the facility.
